banking.question: What happens to my credit score when I take a loan?
banking.description: New and existing loans can affect your credit in several ways: They help you build credit if you successfully make payments. They hurt your credit if you pay late or default on loans. They also reduce your ability to borrow.

banking.question: What typically happens when I go over my spending limit on a credit card?
options: I will have to pay interest on the advance
Nothing, I can just keep spending
I have to call the card company
banking.answer: I will have to pay interest on the advance
banking.description: Some card issuers may allow charges that exceed your credit limit, but they typically charge an over-limit fee of up to $25 the first time you go over your limit and up to $35 if you do it again within six months.

banking.question: What is the difference between a fixed rate and a floating rate loan?
options: In a floating rate loan, the interest rate can change after a certain term
Fixed rate loans are good to buy large houses and not apartments
One can borrow more with floating rate loans
banking.answer: In a floating rate loan, the interest rate can change after a certain term
banking.description: Fixed interest rate loans are loans in which the interest rate charged on the loan will remain fixed for that loan's entire term, no matter what market interest rates do. A variable interest rate loan is a loan in which the interest rate charged on the outstanding balance varies as market interest rates change. As a result, your payments will vary as well.

banking.question: A 15-year loan typically requires higher monthly payments than a 30-year loan but the total interest over the life of the loan will be less.
banking.description: The first thing to look at is the difference in monthly payments between a 15-year mortgage and a 30-year loan. Fifteen-year mortgages do charge lower interest rates than 30-year loans but carry higher monthly payments because you have to pay all principal back in half the time.
